body: A 16-year-old youth was arrested and two other persons were questioned yesterday in the fatal shooting on Wednesday of a student on a high school field in Brooklyn. A fourth individual was still being sought. The victim, Don Devis, 17, of 1355 New York Avenue, was shot while he watched an altercation between two groups on the playing field of James
title: YOUTH ARRESTED, SUSPECT SOUGHT IN SCHOOL DEATH

title: AL DAVIS TACKLES PRO FOOTBALL

body: Daniel J. Lynch, former athletic director and basketball coach at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the Memorial Sloane Kettering Cancer Center. He was 65 years old. A witty and much-sought-after dinner speaker, Mr. Lynch coached Terrier teams that won 278 games during his tenure from 1948 to 1969. His 1956 team, which won 18
title: Daniel Lynch, Ex-Coach, Dies

body: It would not insult Seldon Barlow to be accused of achieving his success with mirrors. Quite the contrary. He and a partner founded Marsel Mirror & Glass Products with $1,900 in 1947. Now it is a $25 million-a-year business, making the decorative mirrors that K mart, Woolworth's, Sears and other chains and houseware stores sell for $5 to $20. Some
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; A MAKER OF MIRRORS FINDS A NEW PLANT IN BROOKLYN

body: BACK in 1954, Louis L. Rosenberg bought a piece of land from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn on Butler Street in Park Slope. He built an industrial building and leased it to the Knickerbocker Toy Company. The Knickerbocker Toy Company moved south 20 years ago. Another tenant moved in. Eventually, Mr. Rosenberg sold the building. And then in
title: PROPERTY; SHOPPING CENTER BUILDER IS HEADING BACK TO BROOKLYN

body: The Brooklyn Republican organization last night endorsed Mayor Koch and thus gave a Democratic mayor, for the first time, the support of four of the city's five Republican county organizations. The vote to endorse the Mayor was Mr. Koch, 39; Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens, 10, and Bernard Rome, 5. There were three abstentions. Mr. Rome, who
title: MAYOR RECEIVES G.O. P. SUPPORT FROM BROOKLYN

body: A retired truck salesman who had helped investigators break up an international drug smuggling ring was shot and killed yesterday on a Brooklyn street hours before he was scheduled to testify in Federal court. The victim, James V. Bennett, 65 years old, of Margate, Fla., was shot twice in the head at close range by two men at Avenue N and East 59th
title: WITNESS IS SLAIN ON BROOKLYN STREET HOURS BEFORE DRUG CASE TESTIMONY

body: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was convicted yesterday of murdering a police officer who was shot several times and then run over and dragged nearly half a mile beneath the speeding car of the fleeing killer. The defendant, Salvatore De Sarno, was convicted after nearly four days of deliberation by the jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The
title: MAN IS CONVICTED IN MURDER OF OFFICER DRAGGED BY A CAR

body: Mayor Koch has turned New York's economic exertions in a novel direction by appointing, of all things, an economist as Deputy Mayor for development. Karen Gerard, a vice president for regional economics at the Chase Manhattan Bank, is known as an outstanding student of the problems of metropolitan New York. With her new badge, she will aim to prove
title: Mayor Koch Deputizes an Economist

body: The story is told that Gertrude Stein, who spent her girlhood in Oakland, once said that the problem with Oakland was, ''When you get there, there isn't any THERE there.'' Like most such acid-etched epigrams, the assessment is more clever than true. Oakland is as palpably there as Brooklyn, for example, to which it is sometimes compared, or
title: OAKLAND, A 'CITY OF CHAMPIONS,' FIGHTS CIVIC INFERIORITY COMPLEX
